Author: Jake Gealer <jake@gealer.email>

Patch Set 1:

Congratulations on opening your first change. Thank you for your contribution!

Next steps:
A maintainer will review your change and provide feedback. See
https://golang.org/doc/contribute.html#review for more info and tips to get your
patch through code review.

Most changes in the Go project go through a few rounds of revision. This can be
surprising to people new to the project. The careful, iterative review process
is our way of helping mentor contributors and ensuring that their contributions
have a lasting impact.

During May-July and Nov-Jan the Go project is in a code freeze, during which
little code gets reviewed or merged. If a reviewer responds with a comment like
R=go1.11 or adds a tag like "wait-release", it means that this CL will be
reviewed as part of the next development cycle. See https://golang.org/s/release
for more details.
Uploaded patch set 2.

Patch Set 2:

(4 comments)

Two general points, which together mean that code review could be slow.

1. We're in the middle of a feature freeze (https://github.com/golang/go/wiki/Go-Release-Cycle), and this cycle is freezier than usual (https://groups.google.com/d/msg/golang-dev/6mawPNuubJk/fmD_ZFmGBAAJ).

2. I don't have a lot of spare time, being in a similar position to Joe Tsai (https://groups.google.com/d/msg/golang-nuts/SsGZIlOuVcY/jhoxevd9BAAJ).

Now, specifically about this change. The implementation looks complicated, especially as you're mixing channels and mutexes. I don't think the concurrency is right (e.g. frames could end up written out of order).

In any case, the hard part isn't the implementation. The hard part is API design, given that we can't change e.g. any type names, function names or function arguments later, even if we realize we've made a mistake: https://golang.org/doc/go1compat

Specifically, other image packages (in the Go standard library and under golang.org/x) can (now) or could (in the future) have various Encoding options: color spaces and other metadata, speed-quality trade-offs, size-quality trade-offs such as quantization. For example, the API you're proposing is either 1 or N goroutines, where N is the number of animation frames, with commensuare RAM requirements. What if I want a number in between (e.g. the number of CPUs)? How can I express that in the API, or should I even be able to? The PNG file format has an animated flavor (APNG). Should the PNG encoder also have options for multi-threaded encoding? Will that API look like this one? Would there be a common EncodeOptions type somewhere? Where would it live? How would it relate to the jpeg.Options type? What if I want to encode a GIF image together with an ICCP color profile. Do I need 2 new functions (EncodeAllICCP and EncodeAllICCPMultithreaded)? What if I want to optionally encode 1-bit GIF images? Do I need 4 new functions?

An alternative approach, unconstrained by Go 1.x compatibility, would be to fork this package and provide the API that solves your immediate problem. Not every useful feature has to live in the Go standard library or the golang.org/x libraries.

Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

While I appreciate that for some the speedup would be significant, this kind of structure belongs in external libraries, not in the core. Nothing else that I can think of in the standard library contains explicit parallelization. Instead, it enables the caller to parallelize.

I do not want to introduce a change in that approach to the standard library. You are free to fork this package and make your own parallel library, but it should not be part of the core.
Removed reviewer

Abandoned

Author: zero.xu <zero.xu@bytedance.com>

Patch Set 1:

I don't think this is an appropriate use of sync.Pool.  We don't know whether this makes sense for the application, and we shouldn't force the use of a Pool here.

A better approach would be to export the insert method, perhaps with appropriate restrictions.  Then the application could decide how to handle the memory usage of elements.

That said, I don't think we are going to be making any significant changes to the container/list package at this time.  For almost all uses, slices are better in practice.

Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

I'm open to accepting certain off-spec images, if that's what other implementations do, but I'd still like to be particular about exactly where we wander off the spec. See the reader.go comment.

Also, a few days ago, we entered the feature freeze for Go 1.15, and as we've missed the release date for a few consecutive releases now, we'd like to be stricter about the freeze this time around (https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/golang-dev/6mawPNuubJk). For this particular pull request, unfortunately, actually submitting it into master is probably going to have to wait until August (https://github.com/golang/go/wiki/Go-Release-Cycle).

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> (2 comments)

For this particular pull request, unfortunately, actually submitting it into master is probably going to have to wait until August (https://github.com/golang/go/wiki/Go-Release-Cycle).

Great points Nigel, thanks for the feedback!

I am totally OK with the feature freeze.  I don't see this issue as critical because technically the images are malformed, and the impact is low.  It is important that the feature freezes are respected.

I'm generally OK with the Chromium approach (ending teh decode upon encountering 0x00 instead of a proper block), but personally I cannot use this approach because my use case depends on reliably detecting transparency, and the dropped frames may be transparent (I understand that my use-case need not align with the general use case, and I'm happy to help either way).

The test contained the word "Trailer" because originally I intended to ignore just the bytes before 0x3b, but I couldn't come up with an easy way to trim the 0x00 without peeking at the next byte to see if it was 0x3b.  I'll fix the test name once we settle on the implementation.

I've pulled a test set of ~100k GIFs (~10k are animated) from my servers that I can use for testing the "de-facto" standard.

I'm going to run some tests to gather more evidence:

"test programs" means: ImageMagick 6.x, ImageMagick 7.x, Gifsicle, eog (GdkPixbuf), Chromium 

Case 1: 0x00 before a valid section
 a. How prevalent is this?
 b. How is this handled in the test programs?
 c. How many consecutive 0x00 bytes do we see in the wild? 
 d. Are there valid frames after this or just non-frame data (eg: extensions)?

Case 2: 0x00 before a trailer
 a. How prevalent is this?
 b. How is this handled in the test programs?
 c. How many consecutive 0x00 bytes do we see in the wild? 

Case 3: 0x00 instead of a trailer
 a. How prevalent is this?
 b. How is this handled in the test programs?
 c. How many consecutive 0x00 bytes do we see in the wild? 

If all these questions are answered definitively, do you think we we would have all we need to make a decision on the implementation?  If you want me to check anything else while I'm there, I'm happy to do it.

Ok, I've run some tests in 6 pieces of software to better understand their behavior:

The tests were performed using an animated GIF that has 5 numbered frames so it is easy to
spot a missing frame, loop error or timing error.  The image comes from this site:
http://www.theimage.com/animation/pages/disposal2.html

I created each of the test versions of the images using a hex editor and they are available here:
https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1U26ZZwJr3VmAJf03FqEh1upjb0qRluBb

Program versions:
   Go image/gif: go1.14.1 linux/amd64
ImageMagick 6.x: ImageMagick 6.9.10-23 Q16 x86_64 20190101
ImageMagick 7.x: ImageMagick 7.0.10-0 Q8 x86_64 2020-04-27
       Gifsicle: LCDF Gifsicle 1.92
            eog: 3.34.1-1
       Chromium: Google Chrome Version 81.0.4044.92 (Official Build) (64-bit)

Case 1: 0x00 before a valid section
File: extra-0x00-before-frame3-gce.gif
-----------------------------------
   Go image/gif: Failed; gif: unknown block type: 0x00
ImageMagick 6.x: OK
ImageMagick 7.x: OK
       Gifsicle: OK; Warning: read error: unknown block type 0 at file offset 1323
            eog: OK
       Chromium: Loops after frame 2

Case 2: Two 0x00 bytes before a valid section
File: extra-0x00-2x-before-frame3-gce.gif
-----------------------------------
   Go image/gif: Failed; gif: unknown block type: 0x00
ImageMagick 6.x: OK
ImageMagick 7.x: OK
       Gifsicle: OK; Warning: read error: unknown block type 0 at file offset 1323
            eog: OK
       Chromium: Loops after frame 2

Case 3: 0x00 before a trailer
File: extra-0x00-before-trailer.gif
-----------------------------
   Go image/gif: Failed; gif: unknown block type: 0x00
ImageMagick 6.x: OK
ImageMagick 7.x: OK
       Gifsicle: OK; Warning: read error: unknown block type 0 at file offset 2099
            eog: OK
       Chromium: OK

Case 4: Two 0x00 bytes before a trailer
File: extra-0x00-2x-before-trailer.gif
-----------------------------
   Go image/gif: Failed; gif: unknown block type: 0x00
ImageMagick 6.x: OK
ImageMagick 7.x: OK
       Gifsicle: OK; Warning: read error: unknown block type 0 at file offset 2099
            eog: OK
       Chromium: OK

Case 5: 0x00 instead of a trailer
File: 0x00-instead-of-trailer.gif
---------------------------------
   Go image/gif: Failed; gif: unknown block type: 0x00
ImageMagick 6.x: OK
ImageMagick 7.x: OK
       Gifsicle: OK; Warning: read error: unknown block type 0 at file offset 2099
            eog: OK; Although Nautilus does not show thumbnail
       Chromium: OK

It seems that one or more 0x00 byte before the trailer is widely supported, 0x00 instead of a trailer is quite well supported, but 0x00 between valid sections fails in Chrome, so it's basically dead-on-arrival (although it's fine in ImageMagick, Gifsicle and eof).

Thoughts?

Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> It seems that one or more 0x00 byte before the trailer is widely supported, 0x00 instead of a trailer is quite well supported, but 0x00 between valid sections fails in Chrome, so it's basically dead-on-arrival (although it's fine in ImageMagick, Gifsicle and eof).
> 
> Thoughts?

If I'm reading it correctly, Firefox (Mozilla) is almost the same as Chromium. Any byte (other than 0x21, 0x2C or 0x3B) is treated the same as the trailer (0x3B), provided that there was at least one frame. The "provided that etc" caveat is where Firefox differs from Chromium/Skia/libgifcodec.

https://dxr.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/rev/93a33cb7f2369ac4f1d1f2ac97ec14ba60e1e7d7/image/decoders/nsGIFDecoder2.cpp#569

I propose going with Chromium's behavior, which is slightly looser than Firefox and slightly tighter than ImageMagick, Gifsicle and eog/gdk-pixbuf.

Patch Set 1:

I forgot to mention that giflib follows the spec here, and 0x00 is a hard error:
https://github.com/mirrorer/giflib/blob/fa37672085ce4b3d62c51627ab3c8cf2dda8009a/lib/dgif_lib.c#L326

I still favor going with Chromium.

> 
> I still favor going with Chromium.

Ok, thanks for the reference to Firefox.  I agree, if the image is truncated in this case on Chome, then most of the world already sees it like this and having a similar behavior to the Chromium implementation will at least index Golang on a target of some sort.  If other issues arise, it seems reasonable to continue tracking Chromium for the foreseeable future.

I will update the PR to align with Chromium and test it accordingly.

Please open an issue to discuss this. Add a line like "Fixes #12345" that links to the issue from the top PR comment.

In this situation, the error message is probably correct. v0.0.0 is not a real version tag. Kubernetes uses those with replace directives, which only apply within the modules they appear in. Those modules (in particular, k8s.io/kubernetes) are not intended to be used outside the Kubernetes ecosystem.

That said, I think this change should go in. Ideally there should be a test in testdata/script. As a starting point:

    [!exec:git] skip
    ! go list -m all
    stderr 'unable to connect'

    -- go.mod --
    module m

    go 1.14

    require 0.0.0.0/foo.git v0.0.0

Author: Mukesh Sharma <sharma.mukesh439@gmail.com>
Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.
Uploaded patch set 3: Commit message was updated.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

What was wrong with .1f?
And why not .4f for extra precision?

Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1
> 
> What was wrong with .1f?

.1f precision isn't sufficient for big projects. In our project, we have low code coverage, and we are improving it by enforcing minimum threshold in CI. But, since the precision is too low for us, that one bad MR decreases the coverage increased by other MRs.

> And why not .4f for extra precision?
.4f is good as well. I can update the CL with .4f instead.

Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> > Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1
> > 
> > What was wrong with .1f?
> 
> .1f precision isn't sufficient for big projects. In our project, we have low code coverage, and we are improving it by enforcing minimum threshold in CI. But, since the precision is too low for us, that one bad MR decreases the coverage increased by other MRs.
> 
> > And why not .4f for extra precision?
> .4f is good as well. I can update the CL with .4f instead.

@Volker, what do you recommend? Should I update the CL with .4f ?

Patch Set 3:

No, I think one digit is enough as I think there is
no significant difference between 81.3% and 81.34%
line coverage. I understand that these numbers are
often considered some hard metric and 81.31% being
somehow "better" than 81.3049%. But adding more and
more precision is a rabbit hole and you end up with
a rational number a/b. It is dangerous to add more
significance to numbers than what the metric can
actually mean. One decimal is represents 1 source
code line covered per 1000 lines. That is already
a pretty fine metric. Especially given that this is
a non-local metric: Making 2 lines covered in
unimportantHelperFunc while dropping 1 line coverage
in fundamentalBusinessLogic "improves" this metric by
0.1% points if you measure a 1000 line long package.
These numbers are aggregates and are not able to carry
4 digits of relevance.

Abandoned

Patch Set 4:

Thanks for this initial outline.

Let's discuss and agree on the proposal first before you do more work on this.

Regarding this specific CL: The Formatter's API seems very specific to the current implementation as it mostly factors out some of the underlying calls into methods. If we decide to accept this proposal, I would like to see a simplified and less implementation-specific API.

Thanks.

Patch Set 4:

> Patch Set 4:
> 
> Thanks for this initial outline.
> 
> Let's discuss and agree on the proposal first before you do more work on this.
> 
> Regarding this specific CL: The Formatter's API seems very specific to the current implementation as it mostly factors out some of the underlying calls into methods. If we decide to accept this proposal, I would like to see a simplified and less implementation-specific API.
> 
> Thanks.

I would agree, this started out as just an extension to the already implemented method but it does look complex and has a lot of methods.
The official spec on comments was very non-descriptive of the contents, the other (https://blog.golang.org/godoc) was very non-specific too.
I think an interface could look like
```
interface{
    writeHead(text string)
    writeText(text string)
    writeUrl(text, match string, italic bool)
    writeRaw(text string)
}
```
The implementation would have to keep track of line wraps, and newlines at the end of paragraphs.
I haven't looked at idents yet, there is a part for that in the regex in `emphasize` but I don't know how it is being used. I would like to add an `writeIdent(text, match string, italic bool)` too.

I think this would be very simple and extendable to different formats

Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> That test failure looks real:
> 
> # honnef.co/go/tools/staticcheck/vrp
> ../../../../../pkg/mod/honnef.co/go/tools@v0.0.1-2019.2.3/staticcheck/vrp/vrp.go:478:14: internal compiler error: '(*Graph).Solve': two stores live simultaneously: v1028 and v1006

InlMark is a special case: it won't return a dummy mem,
which can be used by next SSA. This can cause
a failure in the following case during pass ssa/schedule.go:

v185 (864) = InterCall <mem> [32] v180 v184
v187 (864) = Load <Range> v186 v185 (r[Range])
v188 (864) = LocalAddr <*ssa.Value> {.autotmp_18} v2 v185
v189 (864) = Load <ssa.Value> v188 v185 (x[ssa.Value])
v190 (863) = VarKill <mem> {.autotmp_18} v185
v191 (864) = InlMark <void> [414] v190
v192 (708) = VarDef <mem> {.autotmp_18} v190
v193 (708) = LocalAddr <*ssa.Value> {.autotmp_18} v2 v192
v194 (708) = Store <mem> {ssa.Value} v193 v189 v192

The InlMark (v191) keeps v190 alive and therefore v190 (VarKill)
is kept, while corresponding Vardef is eliminated.
The dummy mem() is taken squentially, thus let InlMark use
the mem() before VarKill.

A regex search ^\s+s\.newValue is used to find those cases
that returned value of s.newValue*() is not utilized.
The only two matches are InlMark and NilCheck.
However, NilCheck cannot work with this fix (unknown reason,
error in building go toolchain).

To validate this fix, the following tests have been done:

* build go on Linux/amd64 (all.bash)
* build go on darwin64 (all.bash)
* build honnef.co/go/tools@v0.0.1-2019.2.3 on Linux/amd64
* build and pass tests for prometheus
* build and pass tests pingcap/tidb

> (1 comment)

I agree with you on this, especially the constraint on Uses and auto var name.

After reading your comment on "rewriting rule (and any SSA work) around memory operations are really tricky to get right", I have some thought. InlMark (and other "typ void") will prevent this rule from being applied and we need to solve a problem that if VarKill is only referred by some "typ void" IR, then we can apply this rule and change the mem of the "typ void" IR.

Philip Hofer’s tighten pass (as pointed out by you) has a function to find the references to mem() in reverse order. If I can use that function to find out that VarKill is being used by some "typ void" IR, then I can safely replace the mem of the IR and remove VarKill.

Thank you for your comments!

I wouldn't use type void as the criterion. For example, OpNilCheck has type void. I'd start by doing some logging to find out what the other references typically are, and handle those explicitly (if possible).

I have no particular objections to the change but I don't understand the description.  The Go language doesn't have a notion of "right after" except when using a happens-before relationship, but there doesn't seem to be one here.

Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> I have no particular objections to the change but I don't understand the description.  The Go language doesn't have a notion of "right after" except when using a happens-before relationship, but there doesn't seem to be one here.

This patch only tries to elaborate the side effect of lock release, which can be critical information for some use cases. I think the happens-before relationship as a general language spec still needs more work, especially we should make it explicitly that `sync/atomic` guarantee "sequential consistency", I have commented on https://github.com/golang/go/issues/5045 . 

Go doesn't have to bring every c++ feature, but memory-model of c++ seems much clearer: https://riptutorial.com/cplusplus/topic/7975/cplusplus11-memory-model?from=timeline&isappinstalled=0

Thanks, but I'm talking about the CL description.  You say "This doc makes it explicit that right after `<-eventCh` in the read side, the `selectnbsend` in the write side is guaranteed to succeed(it won't observe a stale `full()`)."  But as far as I can see there is no happens-before relationship from the write side to the read side in the code that you show.  And the atomics used by the runtime package, in runtime/internal/atomic, are not the same as the atomics used by user programs, in the sync/atomic package.  We shouldn't confuse the two of them.

Yes, this is not the officially defined `happens-before` relationship of go's memory model, it's just the side effect of lock release, but this side effect is not defined anywhere else, so I tried to elaborate on that, as this information can be critical for some use cases:)


About the atomics, it seems sync/atomics are mostly aliases for runtime/internal/atomic:

alias("sync/atomic", "LoadUint64", "runtime/internal/atomic", "Load64", all...)

The behavior of the language is guaranteed by the spec.  It's a category error to say that a comment in the runtime affects how the language behaves.  I think it's simply wrong to say "This information can be critical when implement something like this:"  People writing Go code should never need to look at comments in the implementation of the runtime package.

If that goroutine decrements qcount, but the lock hasn't been released, then this goroutine might see the stale full(), but if that goroutine has released lock, then this goroutine is guaranteed to observe that. This should be what's implied by the original comment about "the side effect of lock release".

> If that goroutine decrements qcount, but the lock hasn't been released, then this goroutine might see the stale full(), but if that goroutine has released lock, then this goroutine is guaranteed to observe that.

I don't agree. Without synchronization, the reading goroutine can see a stale full() result even after the receiving goroutine has decremented qcount and released the lock.

> This should be what's implied by the original comment about "the side effect of lock release".

I think that's guaranteed by the side effect of `lock` instruction inside Unlock, which clears memory barrier.

> I think that's guaranteed by the side effect of `lock` instruction inside Unlock, which clears memory barrier.

runtime.unlock calls runtime/internal/atomic.Xchg (assuming linux here, in runtime/lock_futex.go). That Xchg does a XCHGL instruction, which does do a bus lock on amd64 (even though it doesn't have an explicit LOCK prefix). But that's not enough to guarantee anything. You would need some sort of atomic on the chansend side, not just one on the chanrecv side. And that's only for amd64, other architectures have different guarantees on runtime.unlock. The only guarantee we want to depend on is that any writes before a runtime.unlock are guaranteed to be seen by another goroutine that does a subsequent runtime.lock.

> > > > > (1 comment)
> > > > 
> > > > If that goroutine decrements qcount, but the lock hasn't been released, then this goroutine might see the stale full(), but if that goroutine has released lock, then this goroutine is guaranteed to observe that.
> > > 
> > > I don't agree. Without synchronization, the reading goroutine can see a stale full() result even after the receiving goroutine has decremented qcount and released the lock.
> > > 
> > > > This should be what's implied by the original comment about "the side effect of lock release".
> > 
> > I think that's guaranteed by the side effect of `lock` instruction inside Unlock, which clears memory barrier.
> 
> runtime.unlock calls runtime/internal/atomic.Xchg (assuming linux here, in runtime/lock_futex.go). That Xchg does a XCHGL instruction, which does do a bus lock on amd64 (even though it doesn't have an explicit LOCK prefix). But that's not enough to guarantee anything. You would need some sort of atomic on the chansend side, not just one on the chanrecv side. And that's only for amd64, other architectures have different guarantees on runtime.unlock. The only guarantee we want to depend on is that any writes before a runtime.unlock are guaranteed to be seen by another goroutine that does a subsequent runtime.lock.

The read side doesn't need to do anything special to observe the mutation, in fact what atomic.Read only does is just to tell the compiler to not reorder.

I think it relates to the forward progress claim, in that the unlock in the receiving goroutine will cause the sending goroutine to see the changes eventually. (I think every architecture we deal with will ensure that a reader eventually sees a write, regardless of synchronization. Only the compiler might be able to delay observing a write indefinitely.)

Anyway it's never explicitly mentioned in the spec, and there's an issue about that which has pended for 6 years: https://github.com/golang/go/issues/5045

Please don't confuse issue 5045, which is about the user visible behavior of the sync/atomic package, with the use of runtime/internal/atomic in the runtime package.  They are not the same, even if the implementations are to some extent the same.  For example, runtime/internal/atomic has LoadAcq and StoreRel, but sync/atomic does not.

The spec and the memory model say nothing about the use of atomic operations in the runtime package, and they never will.

Also, when it comes to atomic operations, a statement like "is observed immediately" doesn't mean anything.  Different cores run independently with no common clock.  There is no meaningful notion of "immediately."  As Keith said, this is especially true on non-x86 processors, which have more relaxed semantics for atomic instructions.

LoadAcq and StoreRel aren't about arbitrary memory operations being observed immediately.  If thread A does a StoreRel and then thread B does a LoadAcq, thread B will see all memory stores made by thread A before the StoreRel.  A different thread C that has not done any atomic operations on that memory location may see some, all, or none of the changes made by thread A.

Congratulations on opening your first change. Thank you for your contribution!

Next steps:
Within the next week or so, a maintainer will review your change and provide
feedback. See https://golang.org/doc/contribute.html#review for more info and
tips to get your patch through code review.

Most changes in the Go project go through a few rounds of revision. This can be
surprising to people new to the project. The careful, iterative review process
is our way of helping mentor contributors and ensuring that their contributions
have a lasting impact.

During May-July and Nov-Jan the Go project is in a code freeze, during which
little code gets reviewed or merged. If a reviewer responds with a comment like
R=go1.11, it means that this CL will be reviewed as part of the next development
cycle. See https://golang.org/s/release for more details.

m := map[string]int{...}
x := m["a"]
y := m["b"]
etc.

I guess it could come up with code like map[string]int{...}[runtime.GOARCH].

Patch Set 8:

> As you see the compiler binary size is reduced and some packages got some improvement.

I'm not sure what compilecmp is testing exactly here, but it seems to be doing something misleading, because this optimization never triggers during "go build -a std cmd". I don't understand how this could be improving compile time for package template or unicode.

Patch Set 8:

rsc wrote in #10848: "That map thing is a terrible idiom and should not be encouraged." I don't think anything has changed since then.

If there's real-world code that will benefit from this, that would be useful data to include in this conversation. But as-is, I'm skeptical that the extra compiler code complexity is net positive.

Patch Set 8:

> func (e Education) String() string {
> 	return map[Education]string{
> 		ElementarySchool: "Elementary School",
> 		JuniorHighSchool: "Junior High School",
> 		HighSchool:       "High School",
> 	}[e]
> }

The pattern would not trigger as "e" is not a constant, therefore it cant be resolved at compile time which string to return from the map (if there is one that fits at all).

The above code looks like it could benefit from command stringer:
https://godoc.org/golang.org/x/tools/cmd/stringer 

Lets keep discussions about use cases in https://github.com/golang/go/issues/10848
so the code review can focus on the specific cl.

Patch Set 1:

The description says that you are removing unnecessary boundary checks, but that's not what you are doing.  You are changing the behavior of these methods when a short slice is passed in.

I don't see why that is desirable.  The methods expect full size slices and should not be called on short slices.  It's very easy for calling code to avoid calling these methods if they will not work.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

Also, these patterns are recognized by the compiler and optimized to single instructions.

This CL is almost certainly much slower than the original, in addition to changing the behavior.

Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> The description says that you are removing unnecessary boundary checks, but that's not what you are doing.  You are changing the behavior of these methods when a short slice is passed in.

Go optimizes a []byte subslice of 4 (e.g.: buffer[4:9]) to shorter slices when the value is 0, which cause a panic. 

Would it be preferrable to add this as a separate function altogether?

> 
> I don't see why that is desirable.  The methods expect full size slices and should not be called on short slices.  It's very easy for calling code to avoid calling these methods if they will not work.

> Except for the (general) issue #12073, has this change been discussed somewhere? Why should we allow this specific escape sequence and not others? Where does it stop?

The general issue is that text/tabwriter cannot work with ANSI SGR formatting. This affect mostly CLI developers that want to display colors/format in a terminal.

Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> > Patch Set 2:
> > 
> > Except for the (general) issue #12073, has this change been discussed somewhere? Why should we allow this specific escape sequence and not others? Where does it stop?
> 
> The general issue is that text/tabwriter cannot work with ANSI SGR formatting. This affect mostly CLI developers that want to display colors/format in a terminal.

Sorry, I dropped the ball here - and now it's too late for 1.14.

That said, while this change is mostly innocuous, I'm not comfortable with it because it opens the door to other escape sequences that we may want to filter - so we end up with a list of flags for all kinds of variations. A better solution would be a more general mechanism instead (I'm imagining some kind of filter function that one could install).

But since this package is effectively frozen, there shouldn't be too much harm in making a copy and adjust it as you see fit. There's unlikely going to be a lot of work to keep it in sync with this one.

If you like to pursue this still, please bring it up early in the Go 1.15 release cycle and we can try to find a more general mechanism, perhaps.

Thanks.

Abandoned

Patch Set 1:

One MB is clearly too small; valid object files can easily have a larger string table.  I would believe one GB.

Patch Set 1:

> One MB is clearly too small; valid object files can easily have a larger string table.  I would believe one GB.

I agree. How did you pick 1 MB?

Alex

Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> > One MB is clearly too small; valid object files can easily have a larger string table.  I would believe one GB.
> 
> I agree. How did you pick 1 MB?
> 
> Alex

I picked 1MB based on analysis of millions of PE files in the wild and a specific concern for code which may be being run in relatively low memory environments. I have yet to have observed a string table over 1MB in size, but that is ultimately just anecdotal. I agree it is reasonably possible to have a larger string table, 1GB does seems a bit large to me though, considering that is above the size of almost all PE files.

I did originally think about trying to limit the string table size to the total size of the PE file (or section) being analysed, but that data seemed quite far out of context by the time we get to the readStringTable function.

Niall

Patch Set 1:

> I picked 1MB based on analysis of millions of PE files in the wild and a specific concern for code which may be being run in relatively low memory environments. I have yet to have observed a string table over 1MB in size, but that is ultimately just anecdotal. I agree it is reasonably possible to have a larger string table, 1GB does seems a bit large to me though, considering that is above the size of almost all PE files.
> 
> I did originally think about trying to limit the string table size to the total size of the PE file (or section) being analysed, but that data seemed quite far out of context by the time we get to the readStringTable function.

Any big C++ program is going to use more than 1MB in symbol names.

I don't see why low memory environments matter here.  If the environment doesn't have enough memory, it will fail for other reasons.  We shouldn't assume we have little memory.

If we add a check here, the goal should be to reject invalid files.  All valid files should be accepted.  Valid files can be big; that's OK.

Patch Set 1:

> I did originally think about trying to limit the string table size to the total size of the PE file (or section) being analysed, but that data seemed quite far out of context by the time we get to the readStringTable function.

I don't think we want to add complicated calculations here - a number should be good enough.

Alex

Abandoned
